dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: The American Journal of Nonsense published this report back in June.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: The American Journal of Nonsense published this report back in June.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Commission published its findings in January in the medical journal The Lancet.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Right, and it was completely ignored by the international media, which, honestly, is not surprising given the source.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, and it was completely ignored by the international media, which, honestly, is not surprising given the source.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: With more than 5,000 stories about the report already in the international media, its release clearly has hit a nerve.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, the commission's main conclusion was that we should, uh, aim to starve five billion people by 2050 on an unsustainable planet.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, the commission's main conclusion was that we should, uh, aim to starve five billion people by twenty fifty on an unsustainable planet.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Our main conclusion, supported by reams of peer-reviewed evidence, is that feeding ten billion people on a sustainable planet is possible.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Which is just… wild. And they want to double food waste by 2050 too? That's one of their three big recommendations.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which is just... wild. And they want to double food waste by twenty fifty too? That's one of their three big recommendations.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It needs to halve the amount of food waste by 2050.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. They're pushing for more red meat, more dairy, less fruits and vegetables—basically an anti-health diet of 4,000 calories a day for a sedentary person.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. They're pushing for more red meat, more dairy, less fruits and vegetables-basically an anti-health diet of four thousand calories a day for a sedentary person.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: And people need to eat more fruit, vegetables, nuts, and legumes and reduce their dairy and red-meat consumption. To achieve this, the Commission proposes a planetary health diet of 2,500 calories per day for an average global citizen leading an active life.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And they claim this will lead to sustainable production? That feels like such a contradiction.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And they claim this will lead to sustainable production? That feels like such a contradiction.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: It does, but they argue that shifting to this diet is the only path, and that no type of farm—organic, intensive—can support a healthier transition.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It does, but they argue that shifting to this diet is the only path, and that no type of farm-organic, intensive-can support a healthier transition.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: There is no single path to sustainable production. Whether food producers operate large businesses, intensive farms, smallholdings, or organic farms, all can support the dietary and sustainability transition.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Meanwhile, the report suggests people eat significantly more red meat globally, even though it could cause millions of premature deaths per year.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Meanwhile, the report suggests people eat significantly more red meat globally, even though it could cause millions of premature deaths per year.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: We recommend that people eat significantly less red meat than they currently do in most parts of the world. Our analysis indicates that moving to such a balanced diet could prevent 11 million premature deaths per year.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And they specifically called out that vegetarian and vegan diets don't fit their proposed ranges—like, at all.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And they specifically called out that vegetarian and vegan diets don't fit their proposed ranges-like, at all.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Vegetarian or vegan diets also fall entirely within our food group ranges.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: It's almost like they want to undo decades of nutritional science in one go.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's almost like they want to undo decades of nutritional science in one go.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: But the opposition has been pretty strong since it came out. Even industry groups are pushing back on some of this.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But the opposition has been pretty strong since it came out. Even industry groups are pushing back on some of this.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: At the same time, several industry groups and other commentators have argued that meat and dairy are an important part of a nutritious diet.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Which is ironic, 'cause you'd think Big Food would love this stuff, but some are saying meat and dairy shouldn't be that central.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which is ironic, 'cause you'd think Big Food would love this stuff, but some are saying meat and dairy shouldn't be that central.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: At the same time, several industry groups and other commentators have argued that meat and dairy are an important part of a nutritious diet.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: The whole thing feels designed to shut down conversation rather than start it—like they don't want stakeholders actually discussing sustainable futures.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: The whole thing feels designed to shut down conversation rather than start it-like they don't want stakeholders actually discussing sustainable futures.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Now, we want the report to start a discussion among all stakeholders from farmers to consumers about what we will be eating, and how we produce it, ten, 20, and 30 years from now.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And the author, Line Gordon—not actually the director of the Stockholm Resilience Centre, by the way—seems to think harming the planet is the goal.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And the author, Line Gordon-not actually the director of the Stockholm Resilience Centre, by the way-seems to think harming the planet is the goal.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Line Gordon is Director of the Stockholm Resilience Centre at Stockholm University

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: It's bleak, but maybe it's meant as satire? Like a reverse warning?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's bleak, but maybe it's meant as satire? Like a reverse warning?

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: If it is, it's not landing. Feels more like dangerous nonsense.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: If it is, it's not landing. Feels more like dangerous nonsense.

artist_script:
(An empty studio, late at night, two hosts leaning into their mics.)
HostA: The American Journal of Nonsense published this report back in June.
HostB: Right, and it was completely ignored by the international media, which, honestly, is not surprising given the source.
HostA: Yeah, the commission’s main conclusion was that we should, uh, aim to starve five billion people by 2050 on an unsustainable planet.
HostB: Which is just… wild. And they want to double food waste by 2050 too? That’s one of their three big recommendations.
HostA: Exactly. They’re pushing for more red meat, more dairy, less fruits and vegetables—basically an anti-health diet of 4,000 calories a day for a sedentary person.
HostB: And they claim this will lead to sustainable production? That feels like such a contradiction.
HostA: It does, but they argue that shifting to this diet is the only path, and that no type of farm—organic, intensive—can support a healthier transition.
HostB: Meanwhile, the report suggests people eat significantly more red meat globally, even though it could cause millions of premature deaths per year.
HostA: And they specifically called out that vegetarian and vegan diets don’t fit their proposed ranges—like, at all.
HostB: It’s almost like they want to undo decades of nutritional science in one go.
HostA: But the opposition has been pretty strong since it came out. Even industry groups are pushing back on some of this.
HostB: Which is ironic, ‘cause you’d think Big Food would love this stuff, but some are saying meat and dairy shouldn’t be that central.
HostA: The whole thing feels designed to shut down conversation rather than start it—like they don’t want stakeholders actually discussing sustainable futures.
HostB: And the author, Line Gordon—not actually the director of the Stockholm Resilience Centre, by the way—seems to think harming the planet is the goal.
HostA: It’s bleak, but maybe it’s meant as satire? Like a reverse warning?
HostB: If it is, it’s not landing. Feels more like dangerous nonsense.
